components.name: HeaderComponent
components.template:
Acme

Welcome, {{ user.name }}!
components.sourceCode:
import { Component, Input, Output, EventEmitter } from '@angular/core'; import { CommonModule } from '@angular/common'; import { ButtonComponent } from './button.component'; import type { User } from './user'; @Component({ selector: 'storybook-header', standalone: true, imports: [CommonModule, ButtonComponent], template: `

Acme

Welcome, {{ user.name }}!
`, styleUrls: ['./header.css'], }) export class HeaderComponent { @Input() user: User | null = null; @Output() onLogin = new EventEmitter(); @Output() onLogout = new EventEmitter(); @Output() onCreateAccount = new EventEmitter(); }

components.name: PageComponent
components.template:
Pages in Storybook

We recommend building UIs with a component-driven process starting with atomic components and ending with pages.

Render pages with mock data. This makes it easy to build and review page states without needing to navigate to them in your app. Here are some handy patterns for managing page data in Storybook:

  • Use a higher-level connected component. Storybook helps you compose such data from the "args" of child component stories
  • Assemble data in the page component from your services. You can mock these services out using Storybook.

Get a guided tutorial on component-driven development at Storybook tutorials . Read more in the docs .

Tip Adjust the width of the canvas with the Viewports addon in the toolbar
components.sourceCode:
import { Component } from '@angular/core'; import { CommonModule } from '@angular/common'; import { HeaderComponent } from './header.component'; import type { User } from './user'; @Component({ selector: 'storybook-page', standalone: true, imports: [CommonModule, HeaderComponent], template: `

Pages in Storybook

We recommend building UIs with a component-driven process starting with atomic components and ending with pages.

Render pages with mock data. This makes it easy to build and review page states without needing to navigate to them in your app. Here are some handy patterns for managing page data in Storybook:

  • Use a higher-level connected component. Storybook helps you compose such data from the "args" of child component stories
  • Assemble data in the page component from your services. You can mock these services out using Storybook.

Get a guided tutorial on component-driven development at Storybook tutorials . Read more in the docs .

Tip Adjust the width of the canvas with the Viewports addon in the toolbar
`, styleUrls: ['./page.css'], }) export class PageComponent { user: User | null = null; doLogout() { this.user = null; } doLogin() { this.user = { name: 'Jane Doe' }; } doCreateAccount() { this.user = { name: 'Jane Doe' }; } }

components.name: RxjsExamplesComponent
components.templateData:
Here are some RxJS examples. Click a button to expand the details and learn more.

The interval emits a sequential number on the specified interval. This example emits 10 numbers, one each second. For more information see the Interval documentation.

  • {{number}}

The timeout operator will error when an event is not emiited on schedule. For more information see the Timeout documentation.

{{timeoutError.message ? timeoutError : '' }}

The combine latest with operator will combine the latest values from all passed observables and emit them. For more information see the Combine Latest With documentation.

This example just adds numbers together every few milliseconds:

{{combineLatestWithValue ? combineLatestWithValue : '' }}

The concat map operator will merge source observables to an output, waiting for each one to complete before merging the next value. For more information see the Concat Map documentation.

You can click the page to print another set of numbers.

  • {{number}}

The generate operator will create an observable using a state-driven loop and a scheduler to send the messages. For more information see the Generate documentation. Generate is an older, deprecated function.

  • {{number}}

The debounceTime operation will emit a notification after a timeframe has passed with no other events. For more information see the DebounceTime documentation.

{{debounceValue}}

The tap operator is designed to be used with side-effects. For more information see the Tap documentation.

The map and filter functions are used in this example. Map applies a project function to each emitted value and the filter emits items that satisfy a given condition. For more information see the Map and the Filter documentation.
